revised_title: Mechanico-Chemical Anodic Dissolution of Austenitic Stainless Steel in Hot Chloride Solutions
tldr: The authors investigated the effect of mechanical strain on the anodic dissolution of austenitic stainless steel in hot chloride solutions. They found that yielding the metal reduces the activation polarization required for dissolution, assisting the process and potentially explaining the propagation of stress-corrosion cracks in certain types of steel. This phenomenon has not been observed in other metals, such as nickel, titanium, or mild steel, which do not suffer stress-corrosion cracking under similar conditions.
